p: The higher phytotoxic potential of the leaf extracts of parthenium weed noted in this study is consistent with other reports in the literature. Leaf extracts or litter/residues of aboveground parts of parthenium weed exhibited allelopathic effects on a range of monocot and dicot crop, pasture or weed species [ 5, 6, 10, 11, 31]. Aslam et al. [ 31] reported that the leaf extracts and leaf residues of parthenium weed were more inhibitory to the germination and early seedling growth of wild oat ( Avena fatua L.) and little seed canarygrass ( Phalaris minor Retz.), compared to the whole-plant or root extracts and/or residues in the Petri dish and soil bioassays. Parthenium weed allelopathy in field studies has been previously associated with above-ground plant parts [ 10, 13]. However, the phytotoxicity observed in the controlled laboratory assays with extracts at high concentrations is frequently not indicative of allelopathic activity under field conditions [ 32], and our findings are not suggestive of such.
